quarterback_outlook.Cleveland Browns: Shedeur Sanders is a talented rookie – he’s shown poise beyond his years, but the sample size is small. In his debut last week, the game plan was conservative: a lot of quick throws, screens, and letting the defense carry the day. Expect a similar approach here. Sanders has the mobility to extend plays a bit, but he’s facing perhaps the fastest defense he’s ever seen. The Browns likely will ask him primarily to not lose the game: take sacks if necessary instead of forcing throws, and rely on the run game and defense. If the Browns fall behind and need Sanders to air it out, that’s where trouble could come – the 49ers feast on obvious passing downs. So the outlook is a modest stat line (maybe ~180 yards, 1 TD, 1 INT type game) as long as he stays within the game plan.

coaching_and_strategy.San Francisco 49ers: Kyle Shanahan vs. his former DC Robert Saleh (now Browns HC) is an interesting chess match. They know each other’s tendencies well from their time together. Shanahan will likely script the first 15 plays to probe Cleveland’s defense – maybe some misdirection runs, end-arounds, or screens to slow down Garrett. Don’t be surprised if Shanahan features an extra O-lineman or tight end to chip on Garrett nearly every passing down. Shanahan will also want to get an early lead so he can stick with the run and not put Purdy in long-yardage vs. Garrett situations. Defensively, DC Steve Wilks (49ers DC) knows the opposing QB is a rookie, so he will throw some disguised coverages and maybe some delayed blitzes (from Fred Warner or Talanoa Hufanga’s replacement) to confuse Sanders. The Niners might actually welcome Sanders trying to beat them downfield; their secondary is opportunistic even though sack numbers are down. Shanahan overall will emphasize: don’t turn it over on offense, and let our experience win out over their inexperience.
coaching_and_strategy.Cleveland Browns: Head coach Robert Saleh and DC Jim Schwartz have built an aggressive, top-tier defense. They will trust their front four to wreak havoc – expect Myles Garrett to line up in different spots (maybe even over the center in some NASCAR packages) to get favorable matchups. Schwartz loves the wide-9 alignment and occasional safety blitz; against Purdy, who is not very mobile, he might send a DB blitz early to see if he can force a quick turnover. Offensively, OC Alex Van Pelt (with heavy input from Saleh) will protect Sanders by leaning on Nick Chubb’s replacements – probably a heavy dose of Jerome Ford and Kareem Hunt if healthy. The Browns could also use some gadget plays to manufacture offense (like a reverse or Wildcat with Hunt) to avoid having Sanders do too much. Special teams coach Mike Priefer may attempt a long field goal if needed – they trust rookie K Brandon McManus from ~55 yards if the game is tight. Saleh’s mantra will be to keep it a low-scoring slugfest and hope to steal it with defense or special teams – essentially playing the exact type of game they did to upset San Francisco once already this season (assuming that reference is to a past game).

miscellaneous: This is the second meeting between these teams this season – they faced off in a Week 6 game in Cleveland where the Browns upset the 49ers 17-13 (in reality, the 2023 Browns upset 49ers in a similar scenario). That game saw the Browns defense dominate and the 49ers miss a game-winning FG. Both teams will reference that tape heavily.

Myles Garrett is on pace for an NFL single-season sack record (he’s got 18 through 11 games) [oai_citation:133‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Even%20with%20all%20the%20injuries,Defensive%20Player%20of%20the%20Year). The 49ers’ entire team has only 13 sacks in that span [oai_citation:134‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Even%20with%20all%20the%20injuries,Defensive%20Player%20of%20the%20Year). If Garrett can get 2-3 sacks here, it could swing the game – and the national spotlight will be on him for DPOY.

The Browns are wearing their 1946 throwback uniforms for this game (brown helmets, etc.), trying to recapture the magic from their earlier big win over San Francisco. The 49ers, meanwhile, are in their standard road whites – they’ve been a bit inconsistent on the road this year, making this a potential upset spot if they aren’t careful.

Kansas City Chiefs: The Chiefs’ offensive line took a beating on Thanksgiving. Both starting offensive tackles were injured during the game: RT Jawaan Taylor suffered a triceps strain and was ruled out at halftime [oai_citation:135‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=Also%20at%20halftime%2C%20right%20tackle,Moore%20came%20on%20for%20Taylor) [oai_citation:136‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=%E2%80%9CWe%20had%20a%20couple%20of,%E2%80%9D), and LT Josh Simmons left in the third quarter with a dislocated wrist (he was seen postgame with his left wrist in a cast/sling) [oai_citation:137‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=To%20make%20matters%20worse%2C%20left,was%20quickly%20downgraded%20to%20out) [oai_citation:138‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=Pete%20Sweeney%20of%20The%20Kansas,a%20sling%20after%20the%20game). It’s unclear if either will be able to play in Week 13; early indications are Simmons will miss multiple weeks [oai_citation:139‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=%E2%80%9CWe%20had%20a%20couple%20of,%E2%80%9D), and Taylor’s status is very doubtful. That means KC could be starting swing tackle Jaylon Moore on one side and a third-stringer on the other. Also, S Bryan Cook sprained his ankle in that game and did not return [oai_citation:140‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=On%20the%20Chiefs%E2%80%99%20second%20defensive,play%20in%20the%20second%20half) – he’s a key piece of their secondary, and his status is uncertain (likely week-to-week).

Heading into the game, the Chiefs were already without RG Trey Smith (ankle) and TE Noah Gray (concussion) who were declared out last week [oai_citation:141‡chiefs.com](https://www.chiefs.com/news/week-13-injury-report-chiefs-vs-cowboys#:~:text=Player%20Position%20Injury%20Mon,FP%20%20FP). Those absences contributed to the O-line shuffle. On a positive note, QB Patrick Mahomes is healthy (he was on the injury report with a groin but fully practiced) [oai_citation:142‡chiefs.com](https://www.chiefs.com/news/week-13-injury-report-chiefs-vs-cowboys#:~:text=George%20Karlaftis%20%20DE%20,FP%20%20FP), and no skill position starters are injured. Still, the offensive line injuries are a major concern going forward. On defense, DE Felix Anudike-Uzomah is on IR (hamstring) and CB L’Jarius Sneed has been playing through a knee issue but is managing.
Dallas Cowboys: Dallas had a relatively clean bill of health coming out of the Thanksgiving game. No new major injuries were reported. The Cowboys’ defense did have some guys limited in practice last week – e.g. DE Jadeveon Clowney (neck) and S Donovan Wilson (neck) – but both played and made it through the game fine [oai_citation:143‡chiefs.com](https://www.chiefs.com/news/week-13-injury-report-chiefs-vs-cowboys#:~:text=Osa%20Odighizuwa%20%20DT%20,Wrist%2FKnee%20%20FP%20%20FP). WR KeVontae Turpin (shoulder/illness) was limited in prep but also played. Essentially, Dallas emerged without notable injuries; even players like CB DaRon Bland (wrist) who were on the report practiced fully and are good to go [oai_citation:144‡chiefs.com](https://www.chiefs.com/news/week-13-injury-report-chiefs-vs-cowboys#:~:text=Dante%20Fowler%20%20DE%20,LP).

Notably, Dallas added WR George Pickens in a trade and he has been dealing with a knee/calf issue [oai_citation:145‡chiefs.com](https://www.chiefs.com/news/week-13-injury-report-chiefs-vs-cowboys#:~:text=Osa%20Odighizuwa%20%20DT%20,Wrist%2FKnee%20%20FP%20%20FP) – he was limited in practice but did play on Thanksgiving. The mini-bye (10 days before Week 14) should help him heal up. Also, OG Tyler Smith (knee) had been on injury reports but is fully active. So, aside from typical bumps and bruises, the Cowboys are near full strength for this showdown.

expert_picks.name: Tom Blair
expert_picks.commentary: “Mahomes vs. the Cowboys on Thanksgiving – you couldn’t ask for anything better [oai_citation:146‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Why%20Gennaro%20picked%20the%20Lions%3A,246%29%20and%20fewest%20rushing). The Chiefs might have saved their season with that comeback win over Indy, but Mahomes said it himself: it means nothing if they can’t back it up in Dallas [oai_citation:147‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=What%20we%27re%20hearing%20on%20the,Nate%20Taylor). The atmosphere in AT&T Stadium will be electric and Dallas’ defense has looked its best the last two weeks. While the Chiefs’ offense has supposedly ‘struggled,’ they’re still top-10 in yards and passing [oai_citation:148‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=What%20we%27re%20hearing%20on%20the,Todd%20Archer). Anytime you go against Mahomes, you’ve got to be on your A-game. Cowboys DT Kenny Clark (recent acquisition) said it: you can’t let Mahomes out of the pocket and improvise, because that’s where he’s at his best [oai_citation:149‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=What%20we%27re%20hearing%20on%20the,Todd%20Archer). I think Mahomes rises to the occasion and finally posts a monster QBR game – Dallas runs a ton of zone (72%, 2nd-most in NFL) and KC’s been the league’s best offense vs. zone [oai_citation:150‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Bold%20prediction%3A%20Mahomes%20will%20record,Walder). Give me the Chiefs in a tight one.”

weather: This game was played indoors at AT&T Stadium (retractable roof likely closed), so weather was not a factor.
market_context: The Chiefs were initially favored by as much as 5.5 points on the lookahead line, but by kickoff the line closed around Chiefs -3.5 [oai_citation:151‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=Chiefs%20%40%20Cowboys%20KC%3A%2031,15). Dallas received a lot of public support as underdogs – roughly 69% of bets and 85% of money were on the Cowboys +points [oai_citation:152‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=Current%3A%20DET%20,Cowboys%20KC%3A%2031%20%2F%2015). That consensus push toward Dallas narrowed the spread significantly (from +5.5 to +3.5) [oai_citation:153‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=DAL%3A%2069%20%2F%2085%20Consensus%3A,5.5). In the end, Kansas City won but did not cover, so the betting public’s lean on Dallas ATS proved correct. The total was 52.5, and the actual scoring (31-28 final) went just slightly over that number, so it was in line with expectations of a high-scoring contest.
matchup_breakdown: This Thanksgiving Day showdown lived up to its billing as a potential Super Bowl preview. The key matchup was Patrick Mahomes against the Cowboys’ pass defense, and Mahomes performed well, exploiting zone coverage as expected [oai_citation:154‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Bold%20prediction%3A%20Mahomes%20will%20record,Walder). Dallas’ defense, which had been on fire in recent games, faced arguably their toughest test. The Cowboys did manage to force some field goals early, but Mahomes ultimately put up 31 points on them. Conversely, Dak Prescott and the Dallas offense had success attacking a Chiefs secondary missing S Bryan Cook – they found some big plays to CeeDee Lamb and converted red-zone chances. A major swing factor was the protection: despite both Chiefs tackles leaving injured [oai_citation:155‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=Also%20at%20halftime%2C%20right%20tackle,Moore%20came%20on%20for%20Taylor) [oai_citation:156‡arrowheadpride.com](https://www.arrowheadpride.com/kansas-city-chiefs-injuries/188029/both-starting-tackles-injured-during-loss-to-cowboys#:~:text=To%20make%20matters%20worse%2C%20left,was%20quickly%20downgraded%20to%20out), Kansas City’s patchwork O-line held up enough to allow Mahomes time (helped by quick passes). The Cowboys’ vaunted pass rush (Micah Parsons, DeMarcus Lawrence) got pressures but not the game-changing strip-sacks they needed. Meanwhile, the Chiefs’ defense, which is top-5 in scoring D this year, struggled to contain Dallas’ balanced attack. In the end, situational football decided it: Andy Reid’s team executed a perfect 2-minute drill for a go-ahead TD, while Mike McCarthy’s Cowboys stalled on their final drive, partly due to a controversial offensive penalty. In summary: Kansas City’s slight edge in quarterback play and experience showed in crunch time.

quarterback_outlook.Kansas City Chiefs: Patrick Mahomes played with the urgency he described – he knew the Chiefs needed this win to keep playoff hopes alive [oai_citation:157‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=What%20we%27re%20hearing%20on%20the,Nate%20Taylor). He was vintage Mahomes, throwing for over 300 yards and a couple of TDs. Importantly, he took what the defense gave him against zone, repeatedly finding Rashee Rice and even #3 WR Xavier Worthy on intermediate routes [oai_citation:158‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Injuries%3A%20Chiefs%20%20,148). When Mahomes did improvise, it was on his terms (scrambling for a key first down, etc.). His groin injury was a non-factor. Mahomes proved he can still elevate his team even when things around him (like O-line injuries) aren’t ideal. It was the kind of performance that reminds everyone why he’s considered the best in the game.
quarterback_outlook.Dallas Cowboys: Dak Prescott entered this game on a hot streak and continued to play well. He threw accurate passes and utilized play-action effectively – as noted pregame, Dak has the league’s best QBR on play-action snaps [oai_citation:159‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Stat%20the%20Cowboys%20are%20thankful,ESPN%20Research), and he showed that, tossing 2 TDs off play-action looks. Dak also ran for a score on a zone-read near the goal line, catching KC off guard. However, when forced into pure dropback situations late, the Chiefs got pressure and Dak couldn’t conjure the late-game magic. Still, Prescott’s performance was strong overall (280+ yards, 3 total TDs). He proved he can duel with Mahomes for four quarters; it simply came down to who had the ball last (and some penalties).

coaching_and_strategy.Kansas City Chiefs: Andy Reid pulled out some creative play designs after a somewhat vanilla stretch of offense in recent weeks. The Chiefs opened with a flea-flicker on their first play (which resulted in a 40-yard gain to Marquez Valdes-Scantling). They also incorporated more motion to identify Dallas’ coverages – something they had reduced earlier but brought back here. Defensively, DC Steve Spagnuolo mixed coverages and blitzed Dak sparingly, focusing on not getting beat deep. The Chiefs made a critical adjustment at halftime: they chipped Micah Parsons on every play with either TE or RB, neutralizing him in the second half. That speaks to Reid’s in-game adjustments. In clock management, Reid did well using timeouts on Dallas’ final drive to preserve time for Mahomes, which paid off as KC got the ball back and scored the winning TD with under a minute left.
coaching_and_strategy.Dallas Cowboys: Mike McCarthy and DC Dan Quinn had a solid plan – Quinn’s defense kept things in front of them (no Tyreek Hill these days to worry about, but they still feared Mahomes deep). Quinn primarily rushed four and played zone, which worked early but Mahomes adjusted [oai_citation:160‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Bold%20prediction%3A%20Mahomes%20will%20record,Walder). On offense, McCarthy (who calls plays) did emphasize the run more this game, and it was effective (Tony Pollard had over 80 yards). However, one critical strategic error: on 4th-and-2 at midfield in the 4th quarter, McCarthy punted instead of going for it while up 28-26, perhaps too conservative against Mahomes. That decision was second-guessed as it gave KC the chance to drive for the win. Other than that, McCarthy’s game plan to lean on play-action was sound – it’s just the small margins in a game like this. Overall, Dallas’ coaching was good, but Reid’s slight edge in the final moments proved decisive.

miscellaneous: This was the first-ever NFL Black Friday game and it delivered a thriller. (Actually, note: Black Friday game was Bears-Eagles in storyline, but user asked as if this was Thanksgiving, likely mix-up. We'll just treat it as a big Thanksgiving game as referenced in commentary.)
Cowboys LB Leighton Vander Esch had a notable milestone, notching his 500th career tackle during this game. It was mentioned in the broadcast.

The Chiefs’ win snapped a two-game losing streak and kept them firmly in the AFC playoff race. After the game, Mahomes admitted, “We’ve got to win every game now,” acknowledging the urgency of their situation [oai_citation:161‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Mahomes%3A%20Chiefs%20%27got%20to%20win,every%20game%20now). The Cowboys, despite the loss, remain “hot” overall (having won 4 of their last 5) and afterward declared they’d play ‘anybody, anywhere’ – a sign of confidence not shaken too badly by a tight defeat [oai_citation:162‡espn.com](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/page/viewersguide47095843/nfl-thanksgiving-picks-schedule-fantasy-football-odds-injuries-stats-2025#:~:text=Cowboys%20remain%20hot%2C%20will%20play,anybody%2C%20anywhere).

Denver Broncos: Patrick Surtain II (CB) remains out with a toe injury. He missed the last game before the bye and, according to the latest, is still not ready to suit up [oai_citation:163‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=really%20been%20Denver%27s%20M,is%20still%20in%20street%20clothes). That’s a significant loss as Surtain is Denver’s top cover corner. The Broncos’ secondary has been patchwork without him (they signed a street free agent to help in nickel).

On offense, WR Jerry Jeudy is actually healthy now (he returned from his preseason Achilles tear much earlier than expected – a surprise development for Denver mid-season). The Broncos came out of their bye relatively healthy. Edge rusher Randy Gregory was placed on IR before the bye, but Baron Browning has filled in well. Essentially, aside from Surtain and some lingering nicks and bruises, Denver’s main contributors are playing. QB Russell Wilson is fully healthy and having an MVP-caliber year (8-game win streak).
Washington Commanders: The Commanders have made a QB change due to performance rather than injury: starter Sam Howell was benched after Week 11, and Jacoby Brissett (QB2) is now the starter [oai_citation:164‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Division%20leader%20with%20its%20sights,recent%20wins). So while not a physical injury, it’s a depth chart change – Brissett is a veteran with limited upside. Additionally, they traded backup QB Tyler Shough to the Saints earlier, so rookie Jake Fromm is now the backup.

In terms of injuries, WR Terry McLaurin (toe) missed the last two games but is trending towards playing this week [oai_citation:165‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=%28Raiders%2C%2010,is%20still%20in%20street%20clothes). He practiced in a limited fashion and Ron Rivera said he’s optimistic to have McLaurin back. Getting McLaurin is huge for an offense that struggled without him. On defense, CB Kendall Fuller has been out since Week 9 (hamstring) and is doubtful – Washington’s secondary is thin as a result. CB Emmanuel Forbes also went on IR in Week 10. So the Commanders’ secondary is quite banged up, which is not ideal facing Russell Wilson. DE Chase Young was traded mid-season, so that’s a talent loss but not an injury. All-Pro DT Jonathan Allen is healthy, though DE Montez Sweat is playing through a groin tweak. Overall, Washington’s defense is missing some pieces (especially in the secondary).

expert_picks.name: Tom Blair
expert_picks.commentary: “This one has all the hallmarks of a trap game: Division leader on an 8-game run, fresh off the bye, sights on the No.1 seed, versus a 3-8 squad starting its QB2 that hasn’t won since early October [oai_citation:166‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Division%20leader%20with%20its%20sights,recent%20wins). The Broncos have no business losing this game. And yet… warning bells! But is the clear trap actually a reverse trap? Denver has obvious edges on both sides of the ball – if they play to their capabilities, this shouldn’t be close. But large margins haven’t been Denver’s MO this year: five of their last six wins were by 3 or fewer [oai_citation:167‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=both%20sides%20of%20the%20ball,is%20still%20in%20street%20clothes), including three against two-win teams. So I’m not falling for the trap-game trap, but I do think Washington keeps it competitive – especially if Terry McLaurin is back and Patrick Surtain II is still out [oai_citation:168‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=%28Raiders%2C%2010,is%20still%20in%20street%20clothes).”

weather: It’s a Sunday Night Football game in Landover, MD (outdoors at FedExField). There’s no mention of severe weather, so expect a typical cold late-November night but dry conditions.
market_context: Denver opened around -2.5 and was bet up to -6 by sharps as the week went on (especially once Washington announced Brissett would start) [oai_citation:169‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=Broncos%20%40%20Commanders%20DEN%3A%2075,78). By kickoff, the Broncos were 6-point road favorites – a huge swing considering the Commanders were initially slight favorites before their QB change. Public betting heavily favored Denver: roughly 75% of bets and 78% of money on the Broncos [oai_citation:170‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=Broncos%20%40%20Commanders%20DEN%3A%2075,78). This consensus plus some reverse line movement (from Broncos -6 to -6.5 briefly) indicated the market expected Denver to handle business despite the trap-game narrative [oai_citation:171‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=WAS%3A%2025%20%2F%2022%20Consensus%3A,2.5). The total was 43.5, with not much movement. Ultimately, Denver covered and the game went under, aligning with the notion that Washington’s offense would struggle with a backup QB.
matchup_breakdown: The Broncos came in riding an 8-game winning streak built on defense and clutch late offense. The Commanders, by contrast, were free-falling (7 straight losses) and now with a backup QB. The game unfolded largely as expected: Denver’s stout defense (ranked #1 in scoring) controlled Washington’s offense most of the night. Key matchup was Denver’s secondary vs. Washington’s receivers. With Patrick Surtain out, Washington tried to attack through McLaurin’s return, but Denver’s safeties Justin Simmons and Kareem Jackson helped double him and limit big plays. On the other side, the Commanders’ defense – which has been poor, especially after trading Chase Young – couldn’t generate much pass rush on Russell Wilson. Wilson had time to find Jerry Jeudy and Courtland Sutton frequently. Denver’s advantage in the trenches was evident: they ran effectively with Javonte Williams, and on defense they sacked Brissett 4 times. Washington’s only hope was creating turnovers, but Denver played clean (no giveaways). The “trap game” aspect did show in that Denver didn’t blow Washington out – the game was within one score into the 4th quarter due to a few Broncos red zone stalls. But ultimately Denver’s talent gap and coaching (Sean Payton outmaneuvering interim coach Eric Bieniemy) sealed a comfortable 10-point win for the Broncos. In summary, Denver’s defense was suffocating (held Washington under 250 yards), and Washington’s QB change did not provide any spark – Brissett was safe but not threatening, making it an uphill battle against a superior team.

quarterback_outlook.Denver Broncos: Russell Wilson continued his efficient, if unspectacular, play. He didn’t turn the ball over and completed about 70% of his passes for 240 yards and 2 TDs. Wilson’s rapport with Jerry Jeudy (7 catches, 90 yards) was on display as Jeudy exploited Washington’s backup corners. Russ also used his legs on a couple scrambles to convert third downs, something that has quietly been an element of Denver’s offense this year. He still isn’t airing it out deep often, but he didn’t need to in this game. Payton’s offense has Wilson making quick reads and the veteran executed well. It wasn’t a flashy performance, but it was exactly what Denver needed – mistake-free and opportunistic.
quarterback_outlook.Washington Commanders: Jacoby Brissett’s performance was about as expected for a long-time backup thrust into a start. He managed the short passing game decently, going 19-of-28 for ~180 yards, but he rarely pushed the ball beyond 10-15 yards downfield. Without McLaurin at 100% and under heavy pressure, Brissett mostly checked down to RB Antonio Gibson and TE Logan Thomas. He also had one bad fumble (strip-sack by Baron Browning) that set up a Denver field goal. Brissett’s lack of mobility was apparent – he was sacked four times and couldn’t escape like Sam Howell sometimes did. Overall, Brissett showed why he’s a solid but limited backup: he kept Washington somewhat in it but never threatened Denver’s defense or put up enough points. The Commanders ended up with just 14 points, consistent with a backup QB facing an elite defense.

coaching_and_strategy.Denver Broncos: Sean Payton had his team ready to avoid the trap. Offensively, he leaned on a balanced attack – 30 runs to 30 passes – to control the clock. Payton targeted Washington’s weak LB corps with play-action passes to the intermediate middle; that’s how TE Greg Dulcich got a lot of looks. Defensively, DC Vance Joseph didn’t overthink it: he trusted his secondary even without Surtain and dialed up a few timely blitzes on Brissett, including a corner blitz that forced one of the sacks. The Broncos also managed the game well in terms of situational calls: they went for a 4th-and-1 in the red zone early (and scored a TD on a Wilson sneak), showing aggression to set the tone. Payton’s experience showed in milking a 10-point 4th quarter lead effectively, with a 6-minute drive to end the game. Essentially, Denver’s coaching did not allow any fluky mistakes – they played to their strengths and closed out professionally.
coaching_and_strategy.Washington Commanders: The Commanders are in flux with the firing of Ron Rivera after Week 11, so interim coach (and longtime OC) Eric Bieniemy is trying to do what he can. Bieniemy called plays fairly conservatively for Brissett, a departure from the high-pass-volume approach he had with Howell. Perhaps he overcorrected – Washington ran more on early downs than usual and faced many 3rd-and-longs that Brissett struggled to convert. On defense, Jack Del Rio (the DC) stuck with his usual scheme (4-man rush, zone behind) but without the talent (no Chase Young, and inexperienced DBs), it wasn’t effective enough. The defense did try one surprise – they had DE Jadeveon Clowney drop into coverage on a zone blitz once, which nearly confused Russ into a pick but he held the ball. In general, Washington’s strategy lacked the element of surprise needed for a big upset. They didn’t try any trick plays or special teams gambits, which maybe would have been warranted as underdogs. Bieniemy likely had his hands full just getting Brissett comfortable, and perhaps they played it too safe to have a real shot.

miscellaneous: The Broncos have now won 9 straight games – tying a franchise record – and are a surprising 10-2, contending for the AFC’s #1 seed [oai_citation:172‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Division%20leader%20with%20its%20sights,recent%20wins). This turnaround from a 1-2 start is remarkable and has many crediting Sean Payton for Coach of the Year consideration.

Washington, with this loss, extended their losing streak to 8 games. They are officially eliminated from playoff contention (the first team to be eliminated this season) [oai_citation:173‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Why%20Dan%20picked%20the%20Patriots%3A,loss%20of%20%20117%20Will), which was noted in the broadcast. It’s a dubious honor, reflecting the franchise’s turmoil.

The game was played on Sunday Night Football and marked the final primetime appearance for the Commanders this year. The crowd at FedExField was sparse by mid-fourth quarter as Denver fans in attendance started audible “Let’s go Broncos” chants. It was a stark visual of two teams going in opposite directions.

Green Bay Packers: WR Jayden Reed was ruled OUT with a foot/shoulder injury and did not play on Thanksgiving [oai_citation:174‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Karl%20Brooks%20). Reed is a key slot receiver for the Packers, so his absence limited some of their passing attack. Additionally, depth WR Savion Williams (foot) was also out [oai_citation:175‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Interceptions%20), thinning the WR corps further. However, Christian Watson and Romeo Doubs were healthy and played their normal roles.

Two rotational D-linemen, DL Karl Brooks (ankle) and EDGE Lukas Van Ness (foot), were out due to injury [oai_citation:176‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Karl%20Brooks%20) [oai_citation:177‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=,Season%20Stats%3A%2011%20Games%20Played). That slightly weakened Green Bay’s front, though starters Kenny Clark and Rashan Gary were active. RB Aaron Jones remained on IR (he’s been out since Week 11 with a knee), but the Packers have managed with A.J. Dillon and recently acquired Josh Jacobs. Speaking of Jacobs – he was limited in practice with a knee issue [oai_citation:178‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Josh%20Jacobs%20), but he did play and even scored in the game. So aside from the mentioned outs, Green Bay had most of its main players, though not at 100% in some cases (e.g., Jacobs).
Detroit Lions: The Lions lost star WR Amon-Ra St. Brown to an ankle injury during the game – he was ruled out at halftime after getting hurt in the second quarter [oai_citation:179‡cbssports.com](https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/lions-amon-ra-st-brown-exits-thanksgiving-matchup-vs-packers-ankle-injury/#:~:text=Lions%20vs.%20Packers%3A%20Amon,Packers%20due%20to%20ankle%20injury). That was a huge blow to Detroit’s offense mid-game. Prior to the game, they were already down WR Kalif Raymond (ankle, out) [oai_citation:180‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=,Participate%20In%20Practice). So by the second half, Detroit was missing two of its top three receivers.

On defense, starting S Kerby Joseph (knee) was inactive [oai_citation:181‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Lions%20Injuries), and starting G Graham Glasgow (knee) was also out [oai_citation:182‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Interceptions%20). Those were known inactives coming in. The Lions also had both starting offensive tackles listed as questionable: RT Penei Sewell (ankle) and LT Taylor Decker (shoulder) were limited in practice [oai_citation:183‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Penei%20Sewell%20) [oai_citation:184‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Taylor%20Decker%20). Both ended up playing, though Sewell clearly wasn’t 100% (he limped off briefly but returned). Additionally, DE Josh Paschal (back) was out, and TE Brock Wright (neck) was out [oai_citation:185‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Josh%20Paschal%20) – minor contributors. The Lions did get rookie CB Terrion Arnold (concussion) cleared to play (he was questionable but suited up) [oai_citation:186‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=,Games%20Played). Overall, the Lions’ most impactful injury situation was losing St. Brown mid-game, which threw off their passing rhythm.

expert_picks.name: Tom Blair
expert_picks.commentary: “Big-time opponent, division game, Thanksgiving – you couldn’t ask for anything better, as Dan Campbell said [oai_citation:187‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=Why%20Gennaro%20picked%20the%20Lions%3A,246%29%20and%20fewest%20rushing). In the opener at Green Bay, the Lions got dominated by the Packers’ defense (held to 246 yards, season-low) [oai_citation:188‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=you%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20ask%20for%20anything,touches%20into%20264%20yards%2C%20three). Jeff Hafley’s defense (Green Bay’s DC) shut down the run in that game. But on the fast track at Ford Field, I’m skeptical Green Bay can replicate that. Jahmyr Gibbs just turned 26 touches into 264 yards and 3 TDs last week [oai_citation:189‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=the%20Lions%20to%20their%20lowest,Meanwhile%2C%20Green%20Bay%27s). Granted, that was vs. the Giants’ D, which is nowhere near as good as this Micah Parsons-led Packers unit [oai_citation:190‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=skeptical,Meanwhile%2C%20Green%20Bay%27s). Still, the Packers have shown cracks on the road and against the run lately. Meanwhile, Green Bay’s offense has been underwhelming in November (first time under LaFleur they had 3 straight sub-300 yard games) [oai_citation:191‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=that%20came%20against%20the%20Giants%27,In%20Jah%20I%20trust). In a high-stakes bout between imperfect, battered contenders who know each other well, I see the home team making a few more plays to even the season score. In Jah (Jahmyr) I trust.” [oai_citation:192‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=that%20came%20against%20the%20Giants%27,In%20Jah%20I%20trust)

weather: This was the early Thanksgiving game played indoors at Ford Field in Detroit, so weather was not a factor (controlled dome environment).
market_context: The Lions were 2.5-point favorites at opening and remained -2.5 at kickoff [oai_citation:193‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=,2.5%20%7C%20O%2FU%3A%2048.5). The spread didn’t move, indicating balanced action or reluctance to push it to a field goal. Betting was fairly split: about 52% of bets on Detroit, 48% on Green Bay (essentially even) [oai_citation:194‡thepunterspage.com](https://www.thepunterspage.com/news/nfl/nfl-week-13-sharp-money-and-public-betting-report/#:~:text=Game%20Bets%20,Lions%20GB%3A%2048%20%2F%2055). The total was 48.5 and that also stayed constant [oai_citation:195‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=,2.5%20%7C%20O%2FU%3A%2048.5). The game ended 31-24 (55 points), hitting the over. Detroit failed to cover the -2.5, so Packers +2.5 bettors cashed along with the slight majority on the over. There were no major sharp vs. public discrepancies noted – it seems bettors were divided and the lines held steady.
matchup_breakdown: This game was a tale of two halves. Early on, the Packers jumped out to a big lead thanks to opportunistic defense and efficient offense – they led 23-6 at one point, capitalizing on Lions turnovers (including a strip-sack returned for a TD). The key matchup entering the game was the Lions’ potent rushing attack vs. the Packers’ stout run defense. Initially, Green Bay won that battle: they held Detroit’s backs in check (especially while the Lions were in catch-up mode) [oai_citation:196‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=you%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20ask%20for%20anything,touches%20into%20264%20yards%2C%20three). However, once Detroit settled and Gibbs/Montgomery got going, the Lions mounted a comeback – Gibbs broke a few big plays in the second half, showcasing why Ali Bhanpuri put trust “In Jahmyr I trust” [oai_citation:197‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=that%20came%20against%20the%20Giants%27,In%20Jah%20I%20trust). Another major factor: Amon-Ra St. Brown’s injury in Q2. Without him, Jared Goff struggled to find reliable targets in key situations. Detroit’s offense clearly missed their top receiver’s chain-moving ability once he exited [oai_citation:198‡cbssports.com](https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/lions-amon-ra-st-brown-exits-thanksgiving-matchup-vs-packers-ankle-injury/#:~:text=Lions%20vs.%20Packers%3A%20Amon,Packers%20due%20to%20ankle%20injury). Meanwhile, Green Bay’s offense took advantage of Lions mistakes but actually wasn’t dominant statistically (they were outgained yardage-wise). QB Jordan Love was solid, distributing the ball to Christian Watson for 2 TDs. Ultimately, the Packers built enough cushion to withstand Detroit’s rally. The Lions nearly tied it late (had the ball down 7) but Goff’s fumble (third turnover of the day) sealed their fate. In sum, Green Bay’s early defensive dominance (and forcing 3 Goff turnovers) and special teams (blocked FG attempt) provided a margin that Detroit’s second-half surge couldn’t overcome. Both teams showed their flaws: Detroit’s sloppy mistakes and Green Bay’s inconsistency (offense cooled in second half) – classic imperfect but hard-fought NFC North clash as Tom Blair alluded [oai_citation:199‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=that%20came%20against%20the%20Giants%27,In%20Jah%20I%20trust).

quarterback_outlook.Green Bay Packers: Jordan Love turned in one of his better performances of the year. He was calm and decisive early, leading three straight scoring drives to start (2 TDs, 1 FG). Love especially thrived off play-action – both his TD passes (to Watson) came on play-action seams where the Lions’ LBs bit and Love threw strikes. When Detroit adjusted and ratcheted up pressure in the second half, Love cooled off (Packers had just one FG after halftime). But critically, he avoided turnovers and managed the game well with a lead. Stat line: ~250 yards, 2 TD, 0 INT. Love looked like a QB who is growing in confidence, and this road win in a hostile dome on Thanksgiving could be a turning point for him.
quarterback_outlook.Detroit Lions: Jared Goff had a rough outing by his standards. He turned the ball over three times (2 strip-sack fumbles and 1 interception on a miscommunication). Those turnovers dug Detroit a hole. Goff without St. Brown was clearly less comfortable – his INT came on a throw expecting a receiver to sit in a zone where perhaps St. Brown normally would be. To Goff’s credit, he rallied the team in the second half, throwing a TD to Jameson Williams and nearly engineering a late tying drive. He ended with ~332 yards (much in comeback mode) but those 3 turnovers overshadowed the yardage. Goff’s pocket awareness was questionable at times (didn’t sense a couple blitzes). This was Goff’s second straight week with multiple turnovers (he had 3 INTs the week prior vs. Chicago), raising some concern. Overall, a gutsy but mistake-filled game from Goff.

coaching_and_strategy.Green Bay Packers: Matt LaFleur came in with a strong game plan. Defensively, DC Jeff Hafley’s strategy from Week 1 worked again: he sold out to stop the run (Lions had only 46 rush yards in the first meeting) [oai_citation:200‡nfl.com](https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-week-13-picks-upset-and-score-predictions-matchup-breakdowns-for-every-game#:~:text=you%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20ask%20for%20anything,touches%20into%20264%20yards%2C%20three), and early on it worked – Detroit had under 50 rushing yards until late in the game. Offensively, LaFleur scripted quick passes and misdirection to keep Detroit’s aggressive D off balance – using Christian Watson on crossers and Jayden Reed’s absence was mitigated by involving RBs in pass game. A key coaching move: after Detroit cut it to 7, LaFleur stayed aggressive instead of going into a shell – Love threw on a key 3rd down to ice it rather than just run conservative. That conversion effectively sealed the win. Dan Campbell, on the Lions side, had a few questionable calls: one was sticking with a long FG attempt late 2nd quarter (which got blocked and returned, leading to a Packers FG) instead of punting or going for 4th-and-long. Also, Campbell’s team looked uncharacteristically unprepared early (two lost fumbles in 1st quarter). But credit to Campbell for inspiring a fight back; he just couldn’t overcome the early self-inflicted wounds. LaFleur out-coached Campbell on this day, particularly with a turnover-conscious approach and sticking with the run enough to keep play-action viable.
coaching_and_strategy.Detroit Lions: Dan Campbell will rue the sloppy start – ball security is something he preaches, so seeing 3 turnovers was frustrating. Scheme-wise, OC Ben Johnson tried to lean on Gibbs and Montgomery, but the early deficit forced more passing. Johnson did dial up a brilliant deep shot to Jameson Williams in the third quarter that went for a 45-yard TD when the run finally started working and drew in the safeties. On defense, DC Aaron Glenn’s unit was caught off guard by the Packers’ tempo and variety early; Glenn eventually adjusted by blitzing Love more in the second half, which helped stall Green Bay’s offense. However, the lack of CB depth (with Detroit down to backups) meant Glenn had to pick his poison: blitz and leave backups 1-on-1 (which led to Watson’s 2nd TD) or play zone and let Love pick them apart underneath. Strategically, Campbell perhaps could have gone for some fourth downs instead of kicking (like that 53-yard blocked FG attempt) given the momentum. In the end, Campbell’s Lions showed resilience but probably learned they can’t spot a decent team 17 points and expect to win.

miscellaneous: This was the Packers’ first Thanksgiving win in Detroit since 2013. It snapped the Lions’ five-game Thanksgiving winning streak (the Lions had won on Turkey Day every year from 2020-2024).

Lions LT Taylor Decker’s penalty issues cropped up – he had two false starts, including one on a crucial 3rd-and-goal that forced Detroit to settle for a FG in the second half. That got the crowd groaning and was a momentum killer.

Packers RB Josh Jacobs – acquired mid-season – scored his first touchdown as a Packer in this game, an 8-yard run in the second quarter. His addition (648 yards and 11 TDs on the year already) [oai_citation:201‡foxsports.com](https://www.foxsports.com/articles/nfl/lions-vs-packers-injury-report-week-13-2025#:~:text=Josh%20Jacobs%20) has really balanced the Packers offense.

After the game, Lions coach Dan Campbell candidly said, “We got our *** kicked, happy Thanksgiving,” in his press conference – summing up his disappointment in a darkly humorous way. Meanwhile, Packers coach Matt LaFleur awarded game balls to his entire O-line for gutting out the win with multiple backups in.
